meanings.definition: The land along the edge of a body of water.
meanings.sent1: The sandy shore was a perfect spot for a picnic.
meanings.sent2: The children played happily on the shore of the lake.
meanings.sent3: The shore looked like a giant sandy playground for the seagulls.
meanings.sent4: The sun set behind the shore, painting the sky in hues of orange and pink.
meanings.sent5: The waves crashed against the shore, creating a soothing sound.

meanings.definition: To support or hold up something.
meanings.sent1: I used a stick to shore up the wobbly table.
meanings.sent2: The pillars were needed to shore the weight of the roof.
meanings.sent3: The idea of using duct tape to shore up the bridge seemed ridiculous.
meanings.sent4: Her encouraging words helped shore up my confidence before the presentation.
meanings.sent5: The additional evidence shored up the prosecutor's case against the suspect.

meanings.definition: To move or push something towards the edge of a body of water.
meanings.sent1: The strong wind helped shore the boat towards the dock.
meanings.sent2: He tried to shore the logs closer to the river for easier transport.
meanings.sent3: The playful otters seemed to enjoy shoring the pebbles into the water.
meanings.sent4: The crowd cheered as the team shored the boat to victory in the race.
meanings.sent5: She used a long stick to shore the fallen leaves into the stream.
